Swift: Core Motion

Friday, April 10, 2015

Overview

Many apple mobile devices have motion APIs. There are many APIs and they all use the CMMotionManager class. Usually you only have 1 instance of this class in a high level area like the AppDelegate. You can get more information about Core Motion here.

Content

Check availability first. deviceMotion checks for all others.

1 import CoreMotion
2 var motionManager = CMMotionManager()
3 
4 var isCoreMotionAvailable = motionManager.accelerometerAvailable
5 isCoreMotionAvailable = motionManager.gyroAvailable
6 isCoreMotionAvailable = motionManager.magnetometerAvailable
7 isCoreMotionAvailable = motionManager.deviceMotionAvailable

Is the hardware active?

1 var motionManager = CMMotionManager()
2 
3 var isHardwareActive = motionManager.accelerometerActive
4 isHardwareActive = motionManager.gyroActive
5 isHardwareActive = motionManager.magnetometerActive
6 isHardwareActive = motionManager.deviceMotionActive

The hardware is on, start looking for updates.

 1 var motionManager = CMMotionManager()
 2 
 3 motionManager.startAccelerometerUpdatesToQueue(queue: NSOperationQueue(), withHandler: {
 4     (accelerometerData, error) in
 5     // do stuff
 6 })
 7 
 8 /*
 9 startGyroUpdatesToQueue()
10 startMagnetometerUpdatesToQueue()
11 startDeviceMotionUpdatesToQueue()
12 */

Stop looking for updates.

1 var motionManager = CMMotionManager()
2 
3 motionManager.stopAccelerometerUpdates()
4 motionManager.stopGyroUpdates()
5 motionManager.stopMagnetometerUpdates()
6 motionManager.stopDeviceMotionUpdates()
